awd_titl_txt: RIDIR: Collaborative Research: DAPPR: Diffusion Analytics for Public Policy Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Stability in social, technical, and financial systems, as well as the capacity of organizations to work across borders, requires consistency in public policy across jurisdictions. However, progress depends upon innovative policy solutions to society's problems. The transmission of laws and regulations across political boundaries averts a conflict between the incentives for innovation and consistency.  The current project will offer a database that allows the tracking of the spread of policies through the US states. The database will be disseminated through project webpages. The web interface will also include advanced analytics that illuminate the pathways through which policies spread. Users will be able to download the data and software for their own custom analysis of policy transmission in the US states. 

Policy diffusion has been a topic of focus across the social sciences for several decades, but due to limitations of data and computational technology, researchers have not taken a comprehensive look at patterns of diffusion across many different policies. The investigators propose to combine cutting-edge methods of text and network analysis to understand how policies, as represented in digitized text, spread through networks connecting the American states. The investigators will develop both data and computational methods that address the most pressing limitations to the study of policy diffusion networks. The project will result in two key contributions: (1) a comprehensive source of data with which to track the movement of policies from one state government to another, across three governing branches, and (2) a user-friendly, open source software package for understanding and visualizing diffusion networks from digitized records of policies. These resources will help researchers, public officials, advocacy groups, and other relevant stakeholders understand how to balance the competing goals of innovation and consistency in public policy.

por.por_cntn:
The main contributions of this project were: (1) a comprehensive source of data with which to track the movement of policies from one state government to another, across three governing branches, and (2) a user-friendly, open source software package for understanding and visualizing diffusion networks from digitized records of policies. These resources will help researchers, public officials, advocacy groups, and other relevant stakeholders understand how to balance the competing goals of innovation and consistency in public policy.

Contribution 1 is complete with most of these data publicly available. Contribution 2 is being completed by the remaining teams who requested no cost extensions. The scope of this award was in data collection with some visualization. 

We have created the largest state court of last resort citation network database currently in existence. From written opinions in all state courts of last resort from 1953-2014, we extract each state court citation from within the written texts. We have completed a program that extracts dozens of pieces of pertinent case level information to use in network analyses. After extracting each case cite, we built two main networks.

First, we have constructed a case-static network. This network is based on the case to case citation behavior in each case. Case A has a direct link to case B if case A cited case B in the opinion. This network has nearly 1.7 million case nodes with 4.3 million links. This network is cross state links only. A within state network would be much larger given within state citation patterns prior to the widescale use of electronic resources within the court.   

Second, we constructed a network between individuals judges who wrote majority, dissenting, and concurring opinions for all cases from 1953-2014. Judge A has a direct link to Judge B if Judge A cited a case that has majority opinion written by judge B. The link is directed link and has a weight equal to the number of citations from judge A to judge B. This network has 2,100 judge nodes with 251,205 unique judge links.

Currently, this data is being incorporated into the data dashboard and analytics tools led by the University of Iowa. Data from this project has led to an extension funded by the National Science Foundation Convergence Accelerator that has allowed us to connect federal courts to these data. At the conclusion of that award, we will have the universe of judicial citation patterns in all federal courts, as well as the court of last resort in all 50 states.
